thread.title: Donald Trump’s Pre-Super Bowl Interview Overnight Ratings Lower Than Barack Obama’s Figures
thread.title_full: Donald Trump’s Pre-Super Bowl Interview Overnight Ratings Lower Than Barack Obama’s Figures

author: Oriana Schwindt
title: Donald Trump’s Pre-Super Bowl Interview Overnight Ratings Lower Than Barack Obama’s Figures
text:
Courtesy of Fox News February 6, 2017 | 09:41AM PT 
President Donald Trump sat down on Sunday afternoon with Fox News for the president’s now-customary pre- Super Bowl interview. The segment with “O’Reilly Factor” host Bill O’Reilly , which aired during Fox Broadcasting’s pre-game coverage around 4 p.m., drew a 7.8 household rating in Nielsen’s metered market overnight ratings. Viewership figures will be available later Monday. 
Here at last we have a true apples-to-apples comparison for a television event with Trump’s predecessor, Barack Obama — or at least as close to one as we’re going to get. Related Kremlin Demands Apology From Fox News After Bill O’Reilly Calls Vladimir Putin ‘A Killer’ 
President Obama’s last three sit-downs before the Super Bowl drew overnight household ratings of 9.2, 10.2, and 11.5. His first pre-Super Bowl interview, with NBC’s Matt Lauer in 2009, brought in an average audience of 21.9 million viewers in Nielsen’s final accounting; the overnight household rating for NBC from 4:30 to 5 p.m was a 9.6. The half-hour of 2011’s Super Bowl pre-game coverage — that included O’Reilly’s highly anticipated interview with Obama — attracted an average audience of 17.3 million. 
There are a few factors that can perhaps affect the ratings of POTUS’ pre-Super Bowl interview: Current political climate, game anticipation, and how close to kickoff the interview aired (Obama’s first interview was shown closer to 5 p.m.; the 2011 one was around 4:30 p.m.). The last one could account for the gap between POTUS 44 and 45’s first interviews — the closer to kickoff, the more people are already tuned in to the network. Filed Under:
